messages.content:
You are a debugging assistant. You will be presented with a failing test, and tools (functions) to access the source code of the system under test (SUT). Your task is to provide a step-by-step explanation of how the bug occurred, based on the failing test and the information you retrieved using tests about the SUT. You will be given 9 chances to interact with functions to gather relevant information. An example answer would look like follows.

Title: Diagnosis of test `testGenerateURLFragment`
Details: The test `testGenerateURLFragment` checks whether HTML entities such as `"` are correctly escaped to their corresponding character by the `StandardToolTipTagFragmentGenerator.generateToolTipFragment` method. However, the test failure indicates that this is not the case. Following the execution path, we find that `StandardToolTipTagFragmentGenerator.generateToolTipFragment` is not escaping any HTML code; instead, it is using its input `toolTipText` as is. Consequently, un-escaped strings are being returned, which leads to the error demonstrated by the test.

After providing this diagnosis, you will be prompted to suggest which methods would be the best locations to be fixed. The answers should be in the form of `ClassName.MethodName(ArgType1, ArgType2, ...)` without commentary (one per line), as your answer will be automatically processed before finally being presented to the user.

The test `['com.google.javascript.jscomp.TypeCheckTest.testBackwardsTypedefUse9()']` failed.
The test looks like:

```java
2677 :   public void testBackwardsTypedefUse9() throws Exception {
2678 :     testTypes( // error occurred here
2679 :         "/** @param {!Array} x */ function g(x) {}" +
2680 :         "/** @this {goog.MyTypedef} */ function f() { g(this); }" +
2681 :         "var goog = {};" +
2682 :         "/** @typedef {(Error|null|undefined)} */ goog.MyTypedef;",
2683 :         "actual parameter 1 of g does not match formal parameter\n" +
2684 :         "found   : Error\n" +
2685 :         "required: Array");
2686 :   }
```

It failed with the following error message and call stack:

```
junit.framework.ComparisonFailure: expected:<[actual parameter 1 of g does not match formal parameter
found   : Error
required: Array]> but was:<[@this type of a function must be an object
Actual type: (Error|null|undefined)]>
	at com.google.javascript.jscomp.TypeCheckTest.testTypes(TypeCheckTest.java:7747)
	at com.google.javascript.jscomp.TypeCheckTest.testTypes(TypeCheckTest.java:7726)
	at com.google.javascript.jscomp.TypeCheckTest.testTypes(TypeCheckTest.java:7670)
	at com.google.javascript.jscomp.TypeCheckTest.testBackwardsTypedefUse9(TypeCheckTest.java:2678)
```

The functions covered by passing tests are less likely to contain bugs. This means that if a test case has successfully passed, the likelihood of a bug existing in the corresponding function is relatively low. The passing tests with the highest token similarity to the failing test looks like:

```2660 :   public void testBackwardsTypedefUse7() throws Exception {
2661 :     testTypes(
2662 :         "/** @return {goog.MyTypedef} */ function f() { return null; }" +
2663 :         "var goog = {};" +
2664 :         "/** @typedef {Object} */ goog.MyTypedef;");
2665 :   }
```

```1694 :   public void testAbstractMethodHandling6() throws Exception {
1695 :     testTypes(
1696 :         "var goog = {};" +
1697 :         "/** @type {Function} */ goog.abstractFn = function() {};" +
1698 :         "/** @param {number} x */ goog.f = abstractFn;" +
1699 :         "goog.f('x');",
1700 :         "actual parameter 1 of goog.f does not match formal parameter\n" +
1701 :         "found   : string\n" +
1702 :         "required: number");
1703 :   }
```

Start by calling the `get_failing_tests_covered_classes` function.

The failing test `com.google.javascript.jscomp.TypeCheckTest.testBackwardsTypedefUse9()` belongs to the class `TypeCheckTest` in the package `com.google.javascript.jscomp`. The classes covered by passing tests in the same package are `DefaultCodingConvention`, `CompilerInput`, `SemanticReverseAbstractInterpreter`, `TypedScopeCreator`, `CheckLevel`, `CompilerOptions`, `AbstractMessageFormatter`, `JSError`, `ClosureCodingConvention`, `ControlFlowGraph`, `DiagnosticGroups`, `JoinOp`, `BasicErrorManager`, `TypeInference`, `JSModule`, `LightweightMessageFormatter`, `ErrorFormat`, `TypeValidator`, `PrepareAst`, `Compiler`, `AnonymousFunctionNamingPolicy`, `DiagnosticType`, `FunctionTypeBuilder`, `InferJSDocInfo`, `LinkedFlowScope`, `ComposeWarningsGuard`, `MemoizedScopeCreator`, `ChainableReverseAbstractInterpreter`, `PassFactory`, `SourceFile`, `GoogleCodingConvention`, `NodeUtil`, `TypeInferencePass`, `SuppressDocWarningsGuard`, `TypeCheck`, `SyntacticScopeCreator`, `WarningsGuard`, `CodingConvention`, `DiagnosticGroup`, `CodeChangeHandler`, `Tracer`, `LoggerErrorManager`, `NodeTraversal`, `JSSourceFile`, `ControlFlowAnalysis`, `RhinoErrorReporter`, `DataFlowAnalysis`, `JsAst`, `DiagnosticGroupWarningsGuard`, `Scope`.

Next, let's retrieve the methods covered by failing tests for the `TypeCheckTest` class.

Based on the available information, provide the signatures of the most likely culprit methods for the bug. Your answer will be processed automatically, so make sure to only answer with the accurate signatures of all likely culprits (in `ClassName.MethodName(ArgType1, ArgType2, ...)` format), without commentary (one per line).
